metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In 1998, I made a pilgrimage to the International Storytelling Center in Jonesborough, Tennessee, seeking some enlightenment

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Several years earlier, as the program director of knowledge management at the World Bank, I had stumbled onto the power of storytelling

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Despite a career of scoffing at such touchy-feely stuff—like most business executives, I knew that analytical was good, anecdotal was bad—I had changed my thinking because I’d seen stories help galvanize an organization around a defined business goal.

In the mid-1990s, that goal was to get people at the World Bank to support efforts at knowledge management—a pretty foreign notion within the organization at the time

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I offered people cogent arguments about the need to gather the knowledge that was scattered throughout the organization

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: They didn’t listen

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I gave PowerPoint presentations that compellingly demonstrated the importance of sharing and leveraging this information

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: My audiences merely looked dazed

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
In desperation, I was ready to try almost anything.

Then in 1996 I began telling people a story:

In June of 1995, a health worker in a tiny town in Zambia went to the Web site of the Centers for Disease Control and got the answer to a question about the treatment for malaria

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Remember that this was in Zambia, one of the poorest countries in the world, and it happened in a tiny place 600 kilometers from the capital city

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But the most striking thing about this picture, at least for us, is that the World Bank isn’t in it

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Despite our know-how on all kinds of poverty-related issues, that knowledge isn’t available to the millions of people who could use it

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Imagine if it were

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Think what an organization we could become.

This simple story helped World Bank staff and managers envision a different kind of future for the organization

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: When knowledge management later became an official corporate priority, I used similar stories to maintain the momentum

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: So I began to wonder how the tool of narrative might be put to work even more effectively

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Being a typically rational manager, I decided to consult the experts.

At the International Storytelling Center, I told the Zambia story to a professional storyteller, J.G

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: “Paw-Paw” Pinkerton, and asked the master what he thought

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: You can imagine my chagrin when he said he didn’t hear a story at all

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: There was no real telling

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: There was no plot

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: There was no building up of the characters

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Who was this health worker in Zambia? And what was her world like? What did it feel like to be in the exotic environment of Zambia, facing the problems she faced? My anecdote, he said, was a pathetic thing, not a story at all

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
I needed to start from scratch if I hoped to turn it into a “real story.”

Was I surprised? Well, not exactly

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: The story was pretty bland

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: There was a problem with this advice from the expert, though

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I knew in my heart it was wrong

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
And with that realization, I was on the brink of an important insight: Beware the well-told story!
The Power of Narrative

But let’s back up a bit

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Do stories really have a role to play in the business world? Believe me, I’m familiar with the skepticism about them

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: When you talk about “storytelling” to a group of hardheaded executives, you’d better be prepared for some eye rolling

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
If the group is polite as well as tough, don’t be surprised if the eyes simply glaze over.

That’s because most executives operate with a particular—and generally justified—mind-set

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Analysis is what drives business thinking

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: It cuts through the fog of myth, gossip, and speculation to get to the hard facts

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: It goes wherever the observations and premises and conclusions take it, undistorted by the hopes or fears of the analyst

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Its strength lies in its objectivity, its impersonality, its heartlessness.

Yet this strength is also a weakness

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Analysis might excite the mind, but it hardly offers a route to the heart

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: And that’s where we must go if we are to motivate people not only to take action but to do so with energy and enthusiasm

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: At a time when corporate survival often requires disruptive change, leadership involves inspiring people to act in unfamiliar, and often unwelcome, ways

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Mind-numbing cascades of numbers or daze-inducing PowerPoint slides won’t achieve this goal

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Even the most logical arguments usually won’t do the trick.

Analysis might excite the mind, but it hardly offers a route to the heart—and that’s where we must go to motivate people.

But effective storytelling often does

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In fact, in certain situations nothing else works

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Although good business arguments are developed through the use of numbers, they are typically approved on the basis of a story—that is, a narrative that links a set of events in some kind of causal sequence

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Storytelling can translate those dry and abstract numbers into compelling pictures of a leader’s goals

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
I saw this happen at the World Bank—by 2000, we were increasingly recognized as leaders in the area of knowledge management—and have seen it in numerous other large organizations since then.

So why was I having problems with the advice I had received from the professional storyteller in Jonesborough?
A “Poorly Told” Story

The timing of my trip to Tennessee was fortunate

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: If I had sought expert advice two years earlier, I might have taken the master’s recommendations without question

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
But I’d had some time to approach the idea of organizational storytelling with a beginner’s mind, free of strictures about “the right way” to tell a story.

It wasn’t that I couldn’t follow Paw-Paw Pinkerton’s recommendations

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I saw immediately how to flesh out my modest anecdote about the health worker in Zambia: You’d dramatically depict her life, the scourge of malaria that she faced in her work, and perhaps the pain and suffering of the patient she was treating that day

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: You’d describe the extraordinary set of events that had led to her being seated in front of a computer screen deep in the hinterland of Zambia

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: You’d describe the false leads she had followed before she came across the CDC Web site

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: You’d build up to the moment of triumph when she found the answer to her question about malaria and vividly describe how that answer was about to transform the life of her patient

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
The story would be a veritable epic.

This “maximalist” account would be more engrossing than my relatively dry anecdote

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But I had learned enough by then to realize that telling the story in this way to a corporate audience would not galvanize implementation of a strange new idea like knowledge management

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I knew that in the modern workplace, people had neither the time nor the patience—remember executives’ general skepticism about storytelling in the first place—to absorb a richly detailed narrative

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
If I was going to hold the attention of my audience, I had to make my point in seconds, not in minutes.

There was another problem

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Even if my audience did take the time to listen to a fully developed tale, my telling it in that fashion would not allow listeners the mental space to relate the story to their own quite different worlds

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Although I was describing a health worker in Zambia, I wanted everyone to focus not on Zambia but on their own situations

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I hoped they would think, “If the CDC can reach a health worker in Zambia, why can’t the World Bank? Why don’t we put our knowledge on the Web and broaden our scope?” But if my listeners were immersed in a saga about that health worker and her patient, they might not have any attention left to ask themselves these questions—or to provide answers

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In other words, I didn’t want my audience too interested in Zambia

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: A minimalist narrative was effective, in fact, because it lacked detail and texture

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
The same characteristic that the professional storyteller saw as a flaw was, for my purposes, a strength.

The professional storyteller saw minimalism as a flaw; for my purposes, it was a strength.

On my return from Jonesborough, I educated myself about the principles of traditional storytelling

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: More than 2,000 years ago, Aristotle, in his Poetics, said stories should have a beginning, a middle, and an end

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: They should include complex characters as well as a plot that incorporates a reversal of fortune and a lesson learned

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Furthermore, the storyteller should be so engaged with the story—visualizing the action, feeling what the characters feel—that the listeners become drawn into the narrative’s world

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Aristotle’s formula has proved successful over the ages, from The Arabian Nights to The Decameron to The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and most Hollywood screenplays.

Despite the narrative power of the traditional story, I knew that it probably wouldn’t spark action in an organization

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In retrospect, though, I realize that my insight blinded me to something else

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Believing that this wonderful and rich tradition had no place in the time-constrained world of modern business was as wrongheaded as thinking that all stories had to be full of detail and color

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I would later see that the well-told story is relevant in a modern organization

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Indeed, a number of surprises about the use of storytelling in organizations awaited me.
Tales of Success and Failure

In December 2000, I left the World Bank and began to consult with companies on their knowledge management and, by extension, their use of organizational stories

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
As part of this work, I once found myself in London with Dave Snowden, a director of IBM’s Institute of Knowledge Management, teaching a master class on storytelling to around 70 executives from private- and public-sector organizations.

During the class’s morning session, I spoke about my experience at the World Bank and how a positive orientation was essential if a narrative like the one about Zambia was to be effective

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But in the afternoon, to my dismay, my fellow presenter emphatically asserted the opposite

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: At IBM and elsewhere, Dave had found purely positive stories to be problematic

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: They were, he said, like the Janet and John children’s stories in the United Kingdom or the Dick and Jane stories in the United States: The characters were so good they made you feel queasy

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: The naughtiest thing Janet and John would do was spill a bottle of water in the yard

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Then they would go and tell their mother about it and promise never to do it again

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Janet would volunteer to help out with the cleanup and John would offer to help wash the car

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: These stories for children reflected a desire to show things as they should be rather than as they are

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In a corporate environment, Dave told his audience, listeners would respond to such rosy tales by conjuring up negative “antistories” about what must have actually happened

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
His message: Beware the positive story!

After the workshop, Dave and I discussed why his stories focused on the negative while mine accentuated the positive

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I could see he had a point, that negative stories can be more powerful than positive ones

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I’d used negative stories myself when trying to teach people the nitty-gritty of any subject

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
The fact is, people learn more from their mistakes than from their successes.

Eventually, however, it dawned on me that our points of view were complementary and that our stories served different purposes: My stories were crafted to motivate people, and Dave’s were designed to share knowledge

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: His stories might describe how and why a team failed to accomplish an objective, with the aim of helping others avoid the same mistakes

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
(To elicit such stories, Dave often had to start by getting people to talk about their successes, even if these accounts were ultimately less useful vehicles for conveying knowledge.) It was then I began to realize that the purpose of telling a story might determine its form.

Granted, even optimistic stories have to be true and believable, since jaded corporate audiences know too well the experience of being presented with half-truths

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Stories told in order to spur action need to make good on their promises and contain sufficient evidence of a positive outcome

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But stories intended mainly to transfer knowledge must be more than true

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Because their objective is to generate understanding and not action, they tend to highlight the pitfalls of ignorance; they are meant not to inspire people but to make them cautious

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Just as the minimalist stories that I told to spark action were different from traditional entertainment stories, so effective knowledge-sharing stories would have negative rather than positive overtones.
A Collective Yawn

Once I saw that different narrative forms could further different business goals, I looked for other ways that managers could make stories work for them

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: A number of distinct story types began to emerge—ones that didn’t necessarily follow Aristotelian guidelines but were nonetheless used to good effect in a variety of organizations

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
(For descriptions of some of them and the purposes for which they might be used, see the sidebar “A Storytelling Catalog.”) I continued to come across unexpected insights about the nature of storytelling within organizations.
For instance, if negative stories have their place, so do “boring” ones

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In his book Talking about Machines, Julian Orr recounts a number of stories that have circulated among Xerox repair technicians

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: While rich in detail, they are even less storylike than my little anecdote about the health care worker in Zambia

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Most of these tales, which present solutions to technical problems, lack a plot and a distinct character

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In fact, they are hardly stories at all, with little to hold the interest of anyone except those close to the often esoteric subject matter

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Why are they compelling even to this limited audience? Because they are driven by a detailed explanation of the cause-and-effect relationship between an action and its consequence

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
For example:

You’ve got a malfunctioning copy machine with an E053 error code, which is supposed to mean a problem in the 24-volt Interlock Power Supply

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But you could chase the source of that 24-volt Interlock problem forever, and you’d never, ever find out what it is

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: If you’re lucky enough, you’ll eventually get an F066 error code, which indicates the true source of the malfunction—namely, a shorted dicorotron

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Apparently, this is happening because the circuitry in the XER board has been changed to prevent the damage that would otherwise occur when a dicorotron shorted

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Before the change in circuitry, a shorted dicorotron would have fried the whole XER board

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Changing the circuitry has prevented damage to the XER board, but it’s created a different issue

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Now an E053 error message doesn’t give you the true source of the machine’s malfunction.

This story, slightly condensed here, doesn’t just describe the technician’s accurate diagnosis of a problem; it also relates why things happened as they did

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
So the account, negative in tone and almost unintelligible to an outsider, is both informative and interesting to its intended audience.

As I continued my investigation, one area of particular interest to me was the link between storytelling and leadership

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I already knew from personal experience how stories could be used as a catalyst for organizational action

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
And I had read in two influential books about leadership—Leading Minds by Howard Gardner and The Leadership Engine by Noel Tichy—how stories could help leaders define their personality for their followers, boosting others’ confidence in the leaders’ integrity and providing some idea of how they might act in a given situation.

I also had seen leaders using narrative to inculcate a positive set of corporate values and beliefs in the hearts and minds of their employees

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Think, for example, of Tyco’s effort to repair its battered value system

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: The company began by creating a straightforward manual that outlined new rules in such areas as sexual harassment, conflicts of interest, and fraud

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: But Eric Pillmore, senior vice president of corporate governance, quickly figured out that, as written, the booklet would merely gather dust on people’s shelves

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: So he threw out what he had done and started again in an attempt to bring the principles alive through narrative

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
The story below became part of the revised guide, as a sidebar in the section on sexual harassment and other forms of intimidating behavior in the workplace:

The entire team jokes about Tom being gay

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Tom has never complained and doesn’t seem to mind, but when Mark is assigned to work with Tom, the jokes turn on Mark

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Now that Mark receives the brunt of the jokes, he tells his supervisor he wants to be reassigned

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
His supervisor complies with Mark’s request.

While the guide clearly lays out the company’s policy on harassment, the simple narrative helps bring the policy to life and provides a starting point for thinking about and discussing the complex issues involved

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Dozens of similar stories illustrate an array of company policies.
An Enticing but Hazy Future

Although these types of stories furthered leadership goals in a relatively predictable way, others I came across were more quirky—particularly ones used to communicate vision

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Noel Tichy writes in The Leadership Engine about the importance of preparing an organization for change

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: He notes that “the best way to get humans to venture into unknown terrain is to make that terrain familiar and desirable by taking them there first in their imaginations.” Aha! I thought

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Here is a place where storytelling, perhaps the most powerful route to people’s imaginations, could prove indispensable.

But as I looked at examples of such stories in a number of arenas, I discovered that most of the successful ones were surprisingly sketchy about the details of the imagined future

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Consider Winston Churchill’s “We Shall Fight on the Beaches” speech and Martin Luther King, Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Neither of these famous addresses came close to describing the future in enough detail that it became, in listeners’ minds, “familiar terrain.”

Over time—and, in part, through my work in corporate scenario planning—I realized why

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Specific predictions about the future are likely to be proved wrong

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Because such predictions almost inevitably differ in major or minor ways from what eventually happens, leaders who proclaim them risk losing people’s confidence

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Consequently, a story designed to prepare people for change needs to evoke the future and conjure up a direction for getting there—but without being too precise

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Think of the corporate future that was laid out in a famous mandate by Jack Welch: “General Electric will be either number one or number two in the field, or we will exit the sector.” This is a clear, but general, description of where Welch wanted to take the company

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
Like my Zambia story, although for different reasons, this statement doesn’t convey too much information.

I also came across stories used in somewhat unusual situations that called for reactive rather than proactive measures

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: These stories counteracted negative ones that circulated like a virus within an organization and threatened to infect the entire body

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Dave Snowden of IBM first pointed out to me how stories could be used in this manner

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
His hypothesis was that you could attach a positive story to a negative one in order to defuse it, as an antibody would neutralize an antigen.

For example, at an IBM manufacturing site for laptop computers in the United Kingdom, stories circulated among the blue-collar workers about the facility’s managers, who were accused of “not doing any real work,” “being overpaid,” and “having no idea what it’s like on the manufacturing line.” But an additional story was injected into the mix: One day, a new site director turned up in a white coat, unannounced and unaccompanied, and sat on the line making ThinkPads

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: He asked workers on the assembly line for help

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: In response, someone asked him, “Why do you earn so much more than I do?” His simple reply: “If you screw up badly, you lose your job

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
If I screw up badly, 3,000 people lose their jobs.”
While not a story in the traditional sense, the manager’s words—and actions—served as a seed for the story that eventually circulated in opposition to the one about managers’ being lazy and overpaid

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: You can imagine the buzz: “Blimey, you should’ve seen how he fumbled with those circuit boards

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: I guess he’ll never work on the line

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence:
But you know, he does have a point about his pay.” The atmosphere at the facility began improving within weeks.• • •

Much work remains to be done in developing a menu of narrative patterns that can be used for different purposes in an organizational setting

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Although the handful of story types that I’ve identified is no more than a start, I hope it inspires leaders to consider the various ways storytelling might be used

metadata.author: Steve Denning
metadata.title: Telling Tales
metadata.sentence: Certainly, the ability to tell the right story at the right time is emerging as an essential leadership skill, one that can help managers cope with, and get business results in, the turbulent world of the twenty-first century.
